Award.AwardTitle: Support for activities related to the 13th International Conference of Mercury as a Global Pollutant
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mercury is a global contaminant whose presence in the biosphere has been increased by human activity. The ocean plays an important role in the global cycling of mercury. Understanding the biogeochemistry of mercury, and its methylated forms, particularly methylmercury, is important for understanding the role of climate change and human activities on the accumulation of methylmercury in seafood. Elevated levels of methylmercury in aquatic organisms are a major concern as there are substantial human health and wildlife effects associated with consuming contaminated fish and shellfish. To promote a forum for exchange of information and synthesis, scientists in 1990 held the first international mercury conference, which has since become a regular conference every 2-3 years. Now known as the International Conference on Mercury as a Global Pollutant (ICMGP), the thirteenth ICMGP is planned for Providence, RI in July 2017. This will be the third time the meeting has been held in the U.S. This award, with contributions from four different divisions of the National Science Foundation, provides support related to U.S. coordination of this conference, primarily in the form of travel support for and mentoring of students.

Planned mentoring activities at the meeting will provide students an excellent opportunity to interact with established and young scientists and to gain insights into publishing their research, writing resumes, networking and finding employment, and writing grants to obtain funding for research. The meeting is the primary forum for the dissemination of new results of mercury research, and promotes international collaboration in research and synthesis. Finally, as methylmercury levels in seafood, freshwater fish and other foods are an important driver for concerns about human and environmental health, the proposed activities at the conference will enhance understanding and lead to better management of the potential health impacts of this element, in all its forms, especially in light of the added impacts, which are not well understood, of climate change. Activities at the meeting will also endeavor to build links with tribal and other groups, and medical practitioners not directly related to the meeting, and to enhance interaction between journalists and scientists to communicate the results of scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funding received was used to support student related activities at the 13th International Conference on Mercury as a Global Pollutant (ICMGP) that took place in mid-July 2017 at the conference center in Providence, RI. This international meeting has been occurring since 1990, and the conference site has been in North and South America, Europe and Asia. The activities that were covered under this project was support for student travel to the meeting and support for specific student activities at the meeting. The primary goal of the funding was to enhance the attendance of young scientists who would not have been able to attend the meeting without support, and to provide opportunities for students to gain knowlwdge and expertise for their professional development.

The students whose travel was supported were activiely involved in the meeting and had a presentation on their research at the meeting. 30 students received support in terms of meeting registration, 17 received support for their accommodation and 11 received support for their travel to the meeting.

The grant also supported student activities at the conference which included a mentor lunch where the students met with mentors based on their topic of choice for their inteaction e.g. publication, academic careers, working in government, NGOs, etc. This interaction involved established scientists, managers and industry personnel and the students, with up to 10 students with each mentor. More than 100 students attended. Additionally, a peer mentoring breakfast was organized to harbor interactions between young scientists, including graduate students and post-docs. This activity allowed for these interactions early at the meeting to foster communication during the meeting and beyond. These activities were positively commented on by both the mentors and the students who attended the lunch or breakfast.

The students who were supported gained from the meeting in terms of their professional development and their skills were improved via this interaction. The students gained from their interactions at the meeting as well as benefiting from their exposure to new science and policy and management of the issues related to mercury in the environment.

Mercury emissions to the environment and their impact are a global concern because of human and wildlife health risks from exposure to methylmercury. There is an international treaty through UNEP - the Minamata Convention - to reduce globally the inputs of mercury to the environment. The meeting provided information that will improve the understanding of both scientists and managers on how to deal with this environmental concern, and the grant allowed for young scientists to meet with established scientists and managers working in the overall field of mercury fate, transport and bioaccumulation into foods consumed by humans.
